body:
You don’t always need to get the consent of the other parent for routine decisions, even if they also have parental responsibility.

If it’s a major decision (for example one of you wants to move abroad with your children) both parents with responsibility must agree in writing.

You can apply for a [Specific Issue Order](https://www.compactlaw.co.uk/free-legal-information/children/specific-issue-order.html) or [Prohibited Steps Order](http://www.lawandparents.co.uk/prohibited-steps-orders-effect-parents.html) if you can’t agree. A judge will then make a decision which is in your children’s best interests.
heading: Making decisions with the other parent
